title: Oxello 9 electric scooter on engine C5065

description.text:
I used 200A controller, battery lipo 22,2V 40000AH, motor c5065 ~2000 watts power.
as in my previous version, there is the problem of heating of the motor. I have solved all problems concerning the adaptation of composite parts, they fit and the plastic can be successful in this decision, but the engine heats up so much that it is impossible to touch by hand. Scooter tested in movement, very comfortable at high speed, overcomes slope of about 10 degrees without any complications due to the adjustment of the gear ratio. The speed at 30% throttle, about 22 km/h above have not tried, observing safety precautions. Feel the upper limit of 35-40 km/H.
If anyone knows the model of the engine, which could be implemented in this task, please write a message, I'll be happy to continue searching for a working solution.
If you decide to repeat, there is another hidden aspect, which is not shown. When the circuit is screwed by screws size M3x20, then the nut will need to solder tin, using a flux and solder tin. Otherwise, the movement will occur promotion screw and emergency braking, because he will fly out the details and hit a jam on the wheel.
The scooter will need napilnikom to remove 3 mm of aluminum for the passage of parts with chain. The single-speed chain. Freewhhel USA 13T, others will not fit.
May also be useful for shiboski to calibrate hit freewheel in the chain - 6 PCs (from M4)

description.text: Use MakerBot Customizer to create a ring which may be used for a variety of purposes.

I was searching for a nice and tidy way to keep my filament stored.  It had to be easy access, take as little room as possible, and I had to be able to keep the filament inside plastic zip-top bags.  
Couldn't find anything to match all of the above, so I made these filament shelf brackets.

Apart from the printed brackets, you will need regular wooden curtain rods, 15mm diameter. Should be easy to find at any decent wood outlet. Printed using 0.3mm layer height, infill at 25% (they need to be strong),
3 perimeters. I did mine in PLA, but ABS should work just as well. The curtain rods snaps in place. no need for any bolts or anything. (apart for the wood screws to mount the brackets :-))

comments.text: Why the zip-top bags?
comments.author: Bengimli

comments.text: Because filament tend to absorb moisture from the air, making it brittle and unusable over time.. A ziptop bag with a bag of silica gel inside will prevent that.

title: PYTHAGOREAN CUP
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Pythagorean cup (also known as a Pythagoras cup, a Greedy Cup or a Tantalus cup) is a form of drinking cup that forces its user to imbibe only in moderation.   
Credited to Pythagoras of Samos, it allows the user to fill the cup with wine up to a certain level. If they fill the cup only to that level, the imbiber may enjoy a drink in peace. If they exhibit gluttony, however, the cup spills its entire contents out of the bottom (onto the lap of the immodest drinker).

We found some waste plywood and concrete reinforcing bar at a building site nearby and developed this part/system for making structures.  
The parts print reasonably well without support on our printers here. In addition to the printed parts, required are 8 bolts/nuts/washers. The ones used are half inch head, quarter inch diameter and 45 mm in length, although 35 mm would work. The length will depend on the diameter of the reo bar. Here in Australia it seems to be about 12 mm. But here in Australia we seek to lock up those seeking asylum and think the future of energy is in fossil fuels so I understand things are different in other parts of the world.  
There's some optimising to do and some complimentary parts may follow. However, it's strong enough for current purposes here as a bedside table and display table at our shop.

title: Acorn Salt and Pepper Shakers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Add some personality to your table with a pair of acorn-shaped salt & pepper shakers. It's almost a no-brainer that the salt shaker be printed in white and the pepper in black. But we're more imaginative than that. And who says the top and bottom need to be the same color. Shake it up and have fun with it. Each shaker consumes about 15 grams of filament in just over an hour. So you could print a bunch for different occasions, for gifts or just to squirrel away. Want to learn how to create designs like this one? An Inventor Studios Tinkercad tutorial walks you through this design. Follow the entire collection to develop and refine your modeling skills. Update: Added STL's for just the bottom, just the top, and the top with an internal support -- because global supports generated by slicers can ruin the threads.

I've printed shakers in both PLA and ABS without a hitch. The top requires that a raft be used, though supports are optional. My experience on other projects has shown me that Slic3r isn't always able to print screw threads very well. If you are have to use Slic3r and ABS I'd encourage you to lay out 2 or more shakers in a single job so that each layer has sufficient time to cool before the next is laid down. A special callout to Formatize for sharing the original acorn design. Brilliant!

description.text:
I finally made the plunge and purchased a 3D printer. After calibrating things and doing a few failed attempts, This
was my first succesful 3D printer on my OWN printer! Yah! The print actually turned out pretty nice but there are still a
few things that will need to be tweaked with my printer. I'm pretty sure the file is good to go though as I ran it through netfab to boot. The object is a small shot or martini glass that I modeled after a set that I bought at walmart. The finished product is sort of cool looking, the obtuse texture
of the base feels cool to hold and touch. I tried filling it with water but there were a few tiny gaps in some of the layers and it leaked and
pooled in the base. Hilarious. But all it would need is a bit of paint and some food grade epoxy and you're good to go, print a set for your next party! Please add comments, give me some likes and support. I will have many more models to come!

title: DIY Micro 4/3 Lens v1.1 single lens design

description.text: Just get a 10x cup magnifier (Carson LL-10 or a clone from Daiso store) and you are ready to make a new lens for your Micro 4/3 camera. The focus length is about 60mm. If you like short focus length, check out the duo lens design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:563276).

It is a self-supported design and should be printed out in thin layer. I print out mine with 0.1 mm layer height but 0.2 mm also work.  
Taking apart the cup magnifier and you will find two optical lens. Just take one and snap in the back of the focus ring.  
The optical lens from Carson LL-10 is plano-convex and the one from Dasio is biconvex. All work fine with DIY Micro4/3 lens but have different distort pattern.

The ball bearing uses 6mm softair ammo and is designed to snap together. No glue necessary. It has an inner diameter of 10mm and 28 on the outside.

This is an updated version of my previous medium format camera. I wanted to make a simple one that I was sure was going to print. The smaller size also means it'll be in better focus when used with a Holga lens and shutter assembly.
You can either just attach your own pinhole to the front or you can print out the holga attachment and mount a Holga lens and shutter assembly right on the front giving you a fully functional camera with a proper shutter.
The size of the images is going to be a little funky (3.6cm wide and 6cm tall) but it works.

The ORD Bot Hadron doesn't have a good system for managing filament so I put together this simple system.  It's a free-standing spool holder and a guide that installs on top of the left vertical rail.  You'll need to drill and tap the rail for M5 screws to secure it.  The filament guides up through the X axis motor standoffs, through the guide and over to the carriage.  Nice and clean.  I use a zip tie to keep the filament from backing up into the drive belt.  The spool holder is sized for full size spools from Protoparadigm, but it should work with most.

title: Tower of Hanoi stackable blocks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a set of stackable blocks. The largest one measures 2" in diameter at the base. I set layer height at .2mm, 3 perimeters, 3 solid layers and infill at 40%. I created these as part of a project where a robotic arm could be taught to solve the Tower of Hanoi problem (look it up and try to solve it BEFORE you cheat and look at the answer).
They're a neat desk toy, too. Enjoy!

These instructions come edited from Wikipedia. The puzzle starts with the [blocks] in a neat stack in ascending order of size, the smallest at the top, thus making a conical shape.
The objective of the puzzle is to move the entire stack to another [position], obeying the following rules:
  • Only one block may be moved at a time.
  • Each move consists of taking the upper block from one of the positions and moving it to another postition on top of the other blocks that may already be present in that position.
  • No block may be placed on top of a smaller block.
    • With three blocks, the puzzle can be solved in seven moves. Autodesk Inventor files uploaded, too!

description.text: Villarrica is one of Chile's most active volcanos. Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.4 million facets). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

OpenForge
=========
Arrow slit tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge Like the ruin tiles, this set only has 2x2 tiles (well, ok, a couple larger tiles). For 2x2, it has all the basics. Wall, Corner, Curved, Corridor and Diagonal. OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    Changelog
    =========
  • 1.0.1 : Added more walls for every combination between 1x1 - 4x4
  • 9/01/2014 - fixed mesh problems with all 1x, 3x & 4x tiles
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Printing

This print has a lot of faces, so slicing can be an issue. on my machine it takes about 4 gigs of memory with slic3r. This is already using decimated faces to generate the model. I'll look into ways to simplify it without reducing the quality, but I'm well aware that slicing this sucker is kind of a pain.
Painting

Painting was done in 4 layers.
  • Paint whole piece in black
  • Heavily dry brush with a dark grey
  • pick at least one other color (that could be stone) and paint some random stones, front and back.
  • dry brush with grey mixed with a little olive
  • lightly dry brush with a light grey, focusing most heavily on edges

title: Customizable pixel art ring (Design your own!)

description.text: Pixel art ring that can be customized with lots of shapes, you can create your own too using a tool I created for this purpose, have fun!

This is a customizable pixel art ring, I created over 10 different pixel art designs that come with this project, but you can create any design using a small Pixel art creator I made,   
Choose one of the existing designs or create your own by following these instructions:  
1- Draw the design here jsfiddle.net/Riham/fUrpC/20/embedded/result/  
2- Click the "Get Array!" button  
3- In Customizer, choose shape = Custom  
4- in the Custom field, paste the generated array  
5- Have fun!  
This is my first project ever, I don't have a makerbot so if you happen to try it, or if you are an expert, your feedback is really appreciated!

A model of the United States right before the start of the Civil War. States are separated based on presidential voting during the Election of 1860. States that voted for different candidates are separated by height (0.125 in for Douglass, 0.250 in for Bell, 0.375 in for Breckinridge, and 0.5 in for Lincoln). Kansas is shown cracked, unorganized territories are shown flat. Based on AndyHogan14's 1860 electoral college map (http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1860.svg)

comments.text:
Feel the first difference of the iPhone 5 is in the design. If the iPhone 4 created a revolution in design, then in the iPhone 5 version, users continue to feel the new innovation in design. Overall, if compared with the iPhone 4, iPhone 4S, the improvement in the design face of the iPhone 5 is not really breakthrough. However, users will feel the difference, much more perfect than the design of the previous generation iPhone. The appearance of the machine is quite beautiful, easy to eye and bring to the user luxury, class, noble with black and white, traditional colors make up the level of Apple today. In terms of size, users will feel a little different. Price iPhone 5 long and thinner than the previous generation iPhone 4 and iPhone 4S. The device has a specification of 123.8 x 586 x 7.6 mm, respectively, its length, width and thickness, respectively. The price of the iPhone 5 is about 18% thinner than the iPhone 4Ss. Because of the difference in size, the weight of the phone is different from the iPhone 4. If the iPhone 4 weighs 137 grams, the device is about 20% lighter weight with the weight of this smart phone is only 112 grams. Thus, iPhone 5 is thin, light, longer than the previous version will bring a very gentle feeling for the user. The size change like this, users will feel the hand held machine is very compact, lightweight. Thin design gives a luxurious, elegant feel to the owner.

This is the Solenoid Version (SV) of my Wobble Ring Stepping Motor, parametric for different solenoid sizes. I have uploaded files for solenoid.stl, solenoidLink.stl and solenoidTop.stl to fit these:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11015 This thing is the sister to this:
thingiverse.com/thing:52299 This thing is the successor to this:

thingiverse.com/thing:15915 Also uses mechadense's epi-hypocycloids from:

All parts are oriented for printing without support. Print 1 each of the following:
basePlate.stl

solenoid.stl

comments.text: The walls of the pins are 0.5 mm thick... I think they should be at least double that.  It's a simple change that I can give a try. I like to include a minimum wall thickness variable in scad models that can be tweaked in the case of features like this.

title: 3D Printer Shutdown Timer, Auto Off Switch

description.text: I wanted the ability of a simple addon module that could shut the printer off after its done doing a print BUT i also wanted it to wait for a while to allow the printer to cool down with the fans running before it gets shut off so i came up with this. Most of the time when i do a long multi-hour print i will start it before going to bed and let it crank away through the night, but the problem is i might not be up before its done doing a 6 hour print and i don't want it sitting idle for a couple hours or more after its done, or all day if i start a print before leaving the house. So here it is, Its a FRM01 Timer Relay Delay Module that i picked up off of eBay, i couldn't find them anywhere else online so i will link it here from the seller i bought mine from. http://www.ebay.com/itm/DC-5V-12V-24V-Multifunction-Self-lock-Relay-PLC-Cycle-Timer-Delay-Time-Module-/261610018926?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&var=&hash=item3ce92c186e If you source these anywhere else take note!!!! There is two versions of this module, one version only has 8 functions, the other version has 18 functions, you need the 18 function version and in 24v to use on most printers like the Makerbot, CTC, Flashforge, Wanhao, etc. You need the 18 function version to use function number 10. Set the module for Function 10, set your shut off delay, T1, for the cooling period you want, i set mine for 10 mins (600 seconds) as this allows plenty of cooling time but also enough time that if i get back after the print cycle is complete i can disable the timer and start another print, set T2 to zero seconds, and then your ready. The seller provided little or no instructions but i found a PDF of the instructions and i included it here. Now all you need is a microswitch, a regular power switch like the kind you can salvage from an old ATX power supply, and a little wiring. I used the dual switch mount from softwarebaer and i included that file as well. But here is the original. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536665 See the hookup diagrams for these modules online, it will explain it a lot better than i can in words but i will try my best to explain as well. Now for the Makerbot the wiring is a bit more in depth, but the other printers is really simple because they don't have the power switch integrated onto the mightyboard. For the Makerbot Rep 1 that i have i soldered a wire to the input side of the rear power switch for power and i soldered another wire to the ground trace on the mightyboard for ground to the relay module. For the other models of printers you can remove the positive from the 24v input plug on the mightyboard and loosen the ground and add your wire there and tighten it back up. You then take the 24v that went to the mightyboard and extend it or replace the wire from the power supply on the clones, or from the input side of the switch on the Makerbot and run that to the relay COM on the module, then install a jumper from the COM to the modules power input on the other end. The ground simply goes to the ground on the modules power input. Now this part is optional if you want to relocate your power switch from the back on the Makerbot's, the other printers have a switch on the back that actually supplies AC power to the 24v power supply mounted underneath. We are only switching the DC side here, so for those with one of the clones you will only be shutting off the 24v to the mightyboard and not shutting off the power supply, but basically the Makerbot has a power supply thats always on since its a big external adapter. If your not going to be using the printer for some time just reach around on the clones and flip off the AC power switch. To relocate the power switch using the two switch mount that i linked above run a wire from the modules NO relay terminal to one side of the switch, the other side goes back to the mightyboard. In the case of the Makerbot you need to solder that wire to the other side of the original switch on the board, for the other clones you just insert that wire into the power terminal block and tighten it down. That takes care of the power routing, now you need the triggering and the bypass/arm switch. For the triggering i used a microswitch, just one i had in the junk box but they are very common. I used a long arm switch that i had and designed a mount for it, which is included. Here is an example of the switch needed. http://www.ebay.com/itm/281124299886?_trksid=p2060778.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT Its a TemCo CN0096 Two 20mm long 3mm screws and nylock nuts hold it in the mount. The mount on mine is just hot melt glued to the base and that holds it fine, but you could use double sided VHB mounting tape, or velcro, etc. The trigger switch and the bypass switch get wired between the +24v and the CH1 input terminal on the module. You need to connect one side of each switch to the +24v and the other side of each switch to the CH1 terminal. On the Microswitch it MUST be a Normally Closed switch or if its a single pole double throw make sure you connect the NC (normally connected) terminal of the switch to CH1. Most microswitches are a SPDT switch with both the NC and NO terminals but some aren't so be aware of this. Operation... To turn the printer on i flip both switches on, the power switch and the bypass/arm switch, the printer turns on. The bypass arm switch keeps power to the CH1 terminal which keeps the relay energized and the timer in standby, I start a print, once the bed raises and the print is going the microswitch has been allowed to switch on taking over the function of the bypass/arm switch, then if i want an auto off with delay for a long print i just flip the bypass/arm switch to OFF. This removes the bypass and now the microswitch is in control. When the print finishes the bed comes down and opens the microswitch, the timer module sees there is no voltage on CH1 and it starts counting down, in my case 600 seconds. After 600 seconds it opens the relay and the power is off to the mightyboard and the printer is off. To re-enable the printer all i have to do the next day is flip the bypass/arm switch back ON and the module turns on the relay and the printer is back on. The added power switch is inline with the relay output, so if something goes bad or i just want to turn it off manually i can flip that switch off as well while the relay is on. On the Makerbot the rear switch is left OFF, but you can always use it to bypass the entire timer circuit and added power switch if its ever needed. This all works great and i only wish i would have built this sooner!!
Makerbot standard settings .2mm layer height, 75% infill, 230c, 110c on the bed, etc.

comments.text: Ow, I was on my way to implementing this, but I've run across two problems.  I have a filament out/jam detector, and when tripped, it does a pause, which sends the platform to the bottom.  This would start the shut-off timer, and if not caught in time, it could ruin a salvageable print.
comments.author: garyacrowellsr

comments.text: Thats two scenarios i never considered in the design, i don't have any automatic filament monitoring, i do have alarms that tell me when it runs out, but beyond that there is nothing that interacts with the printers operation.  If i am going to print something tall enough to actually get the bed that low i generally print it on my Delta printer anyway so not an issue there either.  Sounds like an interesting project though, something that detects when the heater is shut off would work, i thought about that at one time also and started on it then went for the quick and easy instead!  If you do get something working be sure to post about it on Thingiverse!
comments.author: garyacrowellsr

comments.text: Hello, thanks for a great project, I have put it all together, but I have a problem that when my printer is switched on, the bed lowers to the start position, tripping the micro switch to power off. I was wondering if you have a circuit diagram of your setup, so I can see what I am doing wrong, many thanks
comments.author: Tappit

comments.text: The diagram is in the pictures up above but i think i can help describe it.  So the bed lowers at the start of a print and it trips the timer, so it is indeed working as thats what its supposed to do, but at the start of a print you want to disable it, thats what the other toggle switch across the switch that the bed hits is for.  When you start a print you have the bypass switch turned on, just wire it to the same two terminals on the microswitch, when the bed hits the microswitch it opens the circuit, so you have a bypass switch that you turn on to keep that circuit closed, after the print starts and the bed raises up and releases the microswitch then you flip the bypass switch to the off position and the circuit is ready for the bed to come down at the end of the print and trip the microswitch and start the timer.
comments.author: Tappit

title: DIY Micro 4/3 Lens v2.1, Duo lens design

description.text: Just get a 10x cup magnifier (Carson LL-10 or a clone from Daiso store) and you are ready to make 'another' new lens for your Micro 4/3 camera. Basically it share same components as DIY Micro 4/3 Lens v1.1, but the main body is 15 mm shorter and focus ring is 10 mm shorter. By using both optical lens from Carson LL-10 (one on focus ring, another mount on main body), the focus length will be around 42mm. A shapeways version is available here (http://shpws.me/z474)

It is a self-supported design and should be printed out in thin layer. I print out mine with 0.1 mm layer height but 0.2 mm also work.  
Taking apart the cup magnifier and you will find two optical lens.  Take one and snap in the back of the focus ring and another snap in the back of main body.  
The optical lens from Carson LL-10 is plano-convex and the one from Dasio is biconvex. All work fine with DIY Micro4/3 lens but have different distort pattern. Also, different orientation of two plano-convex lens can product different distort effect.

Designed with sketchup 2014/2015
Lampe balon

I've recently got into wiring some coils for metal detectors and the likes. Some of the coils don't require any thing special while others can be vexingly complex. Suffice to say working direcly off the spool just wasn't working for me. There were a bunch of old pens laying around and 20 min later one of them had been repurposed! The stl has support material built into it to help with the end being tapered. I currently have two spools of magnet wire the one pictured is rather stout the other is much longer. Both were taken into account in the design so there is a decent bit of flex. Short spool ~50mm,~40mm
Tall spool ~45mm,~60mm

1) Print Pen Wire guide
2) Cut away support material
3) Find a pen and remove the cap, ink and attatch guide
4) string the wire through the guide and through the pen
5) once the wire has made it through the pen place the spool onto the spool holder
6) wire some coils! Optional: cut a piece of fine sponge to fit inside the pen and a channel half way through that for the wire. It's a bit more work initially loading the wire but it adds just a bit of friction to the equation.

This is an iPhone 5S Document Camera Stand.  The open back and angled design makes it great to use as a document camera with the time lapse feature on the I phone.  Take time lapse videos of drawings or paintings in progress or use it as a regular stand.  The open bottom allows you to have your phone in the stand and still be able to connect your charger.

A bust of a grizzled old alien I drew up in Sculptris.
He's pretty high poly (roughly 100k triangles), so he'll be a pretty good demonstration of your printer's quality.
And if your printer messes up near the end (like in my first attempt), he makes a pretty nice container for your tools!
I've attached the Sculptris file in case you want to make some changes of your own. The base isn't flattened in this version.

I printed with a 0.1mm layer height and 20% infill. It took me around 7 hours to print.
You'll certainly need to use support when printing this (his chin makes this a requirement). I needed to use a brim to hold the support in place. I'm not sure if you will, but keep it in mind.

description.text: 3DITEMS iphone5  case

title: Ultimaker bowden cable repair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fix your cable if you had to cut it! Sometimes my 3mm Plastiks gets stuck in the bowden cable because it has 3,10mm or isn't perfectly round. Since the inner diameter from the cable is 3mm there is no margin.
One plastic got so stuck that it was impossible to remove so i had to cut the tube.

Print twice and use 4x 12mm M3 screws and 4x M3 nuts. Until i upgrade the Ultimaker with a 4/6mm bowden cable i had to fix it. I first tried with (good) tape and cable ties but since it is TeflonÂ® you don't get a good grip.
Finally some 38mm large and quite thick piece of TesaÂ® did the trick. But it wasn't strong enough to hold against the bending. This is a big problem if you want to change the plastic because the two parts of the tube aren't aligned.
This parts keeps about 20mm of the Tube straight and give the tape more grip. Note: This is only a emergency fix. After installing it i startet printing new clamps (for a new 6mm tube) for the nozzle and feeder.

comments.text: are there any bigger tubes for the ultimakr? like 4mm or 3.5mm?

author: obelix

description.text: Since making the TRD sculptures I've been pondering how to add programmable LEDs to them. I worked out one solution yesterday in which I print (in place) a hollow tube inside the TRD sculpture. Since the tube is hollow I can push up within it an AdaFruit NeoPixel strip. I've included two versions, the second iteration has the tube more closely aligned to the shape of the sculpture.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46735 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=46735

Using the following options: full = True
text_thickness = 4
holes = no
nozzle = 0.8
sections = 18
length = 12
outer_radius = 31
text = VBS Oostduinkerke
inner_radius = 26
